 It is unfortunate that the political will does not exist to nationalize the banks. The biggest problem with letting any of the major banks fail is counterparty risk. Let any one of the major banks fail and all the rest will fail as well. If we were to nationalize those banks, that counterparty risk could essentially be eliminated with single declaration...all counterparty contracts between nationalized institutions are now null. Since we already effectively own AIG, that would take about 80% of the counterparty risk in our banking system out. We could also wipe out about 60% of CDS risk at the same time.
 
 There are some good argument against nationalizing the banks as well. Shareholders would be wiped out...including preferred shareholders, which would mean that people with millions and millions, or even billions of dollars, would lose a lot of money. Obviously that is something that has to be avoided at any cost. I do understand and to some degree sympathize with the argument that the government pretty much screws up everything it touches, but at the same time, from a logical standpoint, I have trouble imagining that the government could possibly screw them up worse than they already are. I mean, it may very well be functionally impossible.
